text:
SPEAKER: We will start our
class day ceremony, however,

by honoring five
extraordinary alumni

of the school with our
Alumni Achievement Award.

This is the school's
highest honor,

and these distinguished alumni
have contributed significantly

to their companies
and their communities

while upholding the highest
standards and values
in everything they do.

We hope their example inspires
the students we graduate today

and demonstrates the many
ways in which Harvard Business

School alumni make a
difference in the world.

With help from five members
of the MBA class of 2019,

it is now my pleasure to present
the 2019 Alumni Achievement
Awards.
[APPLAUSE]

APOORVA PASRICHA:
Good afternoon.

My name is Apoorva
Pasricha, and I'm

a proud member of Section
J. It is my distinct honor

to introduce our first recipient
for the alumni achievement
awards, Marla Beck.
Marla Beck--
[APPLAUSE]

Marla Beck grew up in
Oakland, California.
Her mother was a teacher.

Her father ran a
real estate company.

And as a kid, tagging along
on his business dealings

and helping with
the firm's books,

Marla knew that one day
she'd run her own enterprise.

She studied political
economy at UC Berkeley,

worked as a business
analyst at McKinsey,

and came to Harvard to expand
her horizons by studying
business and government.

After working for a
year in private equity,

she launched Bluemercury, a
standalone cosmetics retailer

that pairs prestige
brands with expert advice.

For those who haven't read the
HBS case on Bluemercury that

chronicles how Marla
built the company by going

against the grain,
let me tell you this,

in addition to inventing the
phrase clicks and bricks,

she also was a master of
the pivot before it became
common parlance.

Visit one of Bluemercury's
200 stores today

and you will find it buzzing
with enthusiastic shoppers
and staff.

You also might find Marla
interviewing customers, working

with team members,
and in myriad ways,

modeling her own brand
of authentic leadership.
Congratulations, Marla.
[APPLAUSE]

SPEAKER: Marla Beck, MBA,
MPA, 1998, CEO and co-founder
of Bluemercury.

Creative thinker, you
personalized the beauty of--

the business of beauty,
bringing expert advice

and innovative retailing
to neighborhood shops

and catering to customers and
employees in equal measure.

Adventurous entrepreneur, you've
built a successful enterprise

while serving as a role model
of how to exceed expectations.

Dream big, work hard,
and invest in others.

Marla, today, we honor you
and celebrate your work
as an inspiring entrepreneur.
[APPLAUSE]
KYLE EMORY: Good afternoon.

My name is Kyle Emory, and I
am a proud member of Section E.
[CHEERS]

It is my honor and privilege
to introduce Michael Bloomberg
today.

Mike Bloomberg joined
Salomon Brothers
after graduating from HBS.

15 years later, when the
firm merged with another,

he was fired, an
act that propelled

him to launch a business that
computerized financial data
for investment professionals.

Soon, the Bloomberg
Terminal would revolutionize
the financial world.

Today, the company has 20,000
employees in 120 countries.

In 2001, the Boston
native wanted

to make an impact
on his adopted city
and ran for mayor of New York.

Elected just weeks after the
September 11 terrorist attacks,

Mike served three
successful terms

in what he calls the best
political job in the world.

He then launched a foundation
to address some of society's
biggest challenges.

Through Bloomberg
Philanthropies,

he's given away
more than $6 billion

to support education, public
health, the environment,
and multiple other causes.
[APPLAUSE]

It is hard to imagine
an individual having

such an enormous impact
in any one sector,

yet he has done so as an
entrepreneur, a politician,
and a philanthropist.

Mike takes a practical,
data-driven approach

to problem solving,
he works hard,

and he honors his
humble beginnings.
[APPLAUSE]

SPEAKER: Michael R Bloomberg,
MBA, 1966, founder Bloomberg LP

and Bloomberg Philanthropies,
mayor, New York City,

Business, government,
philanthropy,

your remarkable
cross-sector leadership
has changed the world.

Terminated at Salomon, you
built the Bloomberg Terminal

and revolutionized the
global financial system.

Whether leading New York City
or philanthropic endeavors,

you advocate for those
in need, for the planet,

and for a just society with
benevolence and humility.

Mike, today, we honor
you and celebrate

your extraordinary
contributions to society.
[APPLAUSE]

JORDAN RICHARD-CRAVEN:
Good afternoon.

My name is Jordan
Richard-Craven,

and I'm a proud
member of Section H.
[CHEERS]

I have the distinct honor
today of introducing Michael G
Mullen.

Mike Mullen believes that
personal accountability

is a key tenant of
leadership, and he

takes responsibility for his
own history of rocky starts.

During his first year
at the US Naval Academy,

he was miserable, and his
GPA reflected his mood.

As a Navy lieutenant,
he scraped a buoy

when returning his
first ship to port.

These experiences, he
says, made him stronger.

Ultimately, Mike rose through
the ranks of the Navy,

and in 2007, was asked
to take on the highest

military position in the United
States, Chairman of the Joint
Chiefs of Staff.

Working for presidents George
W Bush and President Barack

Obama, Mike served his
country extraordinarily well.

In addition to allowing gay
and lesbian service members

to serve openly by repealing the
Don't Ask, Don't Tell policy,
and leading the team--
[APPLAUSE]

--and leading the team that
defeated Osama bin Laden,

he was, and remains, an
advocate for the families
of fallen soldiers.

Mike cares deeply
about his country,

and his respect for those
who serve in the military
is both profound and palpable.
Congratulations, Mike.
[APPLAUSE]

SPEAKER: Michael G
Mullen, AMP 109, 1991,

17th Chairman of the
Joint Chiefs of Staff,

admirable Admiral, you
command with compassion,

bringing a voice of reason
to everything you do.

With deep integrity,
you counter terrorism

and comprehend the tragedy of
losing a loved one in service
to their country.

Your thoughtful approach
brings people together

to celebrate their differences
and unite across their shared
values.

Mike, today, we honor
you and celebrate

your exemplary and
compassionate leadership.
[APPLAUSE]
MIKE MURRAY: Hi, everyone.

I'm Mike Murray, a member
of the incredible Section I.
[CHEERS]

Today, I am pleased to
introduce Tracy Palandjian.

Tracy's resilience was
put to a serious test

during her first year
at Harvard College.

Her father back in
Hong Kong died suddenly
of a heart attack.

Tracy went home to
tend to her family

and determined two
things, she needed

to help raise her
two younger brothers,

and she needed to
return to Harvard.

Tracy made good
on both accounts,

making up for lost
academic time,

and enrolling her brothers
in a boarding school

in Massachusetts so that she
could see them regularly.

After earning her MBA
as a Baker Scholar,

Tracy worked as a consultant
and launched a career

using business skills to
tackle social challenges.

She created a nonprofit
consulting practice
at the Parthenon Group.

Next, it was a
natural step for her

to take the helm
of Social Finance

in Boston, where she is
bringing together government,

nonprofits, and
for-profit investors

to build new models
for social change.

Tracy is an optimist
who tackles and solves

difficult problems with equal
parts confidence and humility.
Congratulations, Tracy.
[APPLAUSE]

SPEAKER: Tracy P
Palandjian, MBA, 1997,

CEO and co-founder
of Social Finance,

inspired an inspiring
impact investor,

you make a difference
in the lives of others

by forging unlikely
partnerships and thinking
beyond the bottom line.

Board member, entrepreneur,
CEO, with vision and enthusiasm,

you set an example
of how to lead

with conviction and compassion
in every aspect of your life.

Tracy, today, we honor you and
celebrate your tireless work

addressing society's
toughest challenges.
Congratulations.
[APPLAUSE]

SHANNON WOOD: Hi,
I'm Shannon wood,

and I'm a proud
member of Section G.
[CHEERS]

And I have the distinct honor
of introducing Álvaro Rodríguez.

Álvaro cites two important
factors from his youth that

deeply shaped him, his mother,
and the sport of rowing.

Growing up in Mexico
City, he saw his mother

work 12 hour days and
sacrifice everything
in order to raise her two sons.

From her, he learned the value
of hard work and of family.

From rowing, he
learned the importance
of discipline and teamwork.

These influences inspired
one of his personal often

repeated mottos,
swing for the fences.

Álvaro joined Axion
International after earning his
MBA.

There, he learned the
ropes of microfinance
from his mentor, Michael Chu.

He then returned
to Mexico and held

a series of leadership positions
in the corporate world.

In 2007, Álvaro and
Michael launched IGNIA,

a venture capital firm focused
on entrepreneurs who build

companies that serve the
emerging middle class.

IGNIA, now the largest
VC firm in Mexico,

is fostering market
solutions to social problems

while having a positive
impact on Mexico's economy.

Álvaro is committed to making
sure his fellow Mexicans have
every opportunity to thrive.
Congratulations, Álvaro.
[APPLAUSE]

SPEAKER: Álvaro Rodriguez
Arregui, MBA, 1995,

co-founder and managing
partner of IGNIA.

Magnanimous son of Mexico, you
apply your considerable talents

to ensuring your
homeland succeeds.

Investing in
entrepreneurs, your passion

is contagious,
inspiring individuals
to build a bright future.

Devoted family man
and friend, you've

charted your own
course, building

a life that is proof positive
that a rising tide lifts
all boats.

Álvaro, today, we honor you and
celebrate the profound impact
you have had in the world.
Congratulations.
[APPLAUSE]
